overview_of_class:
This course will give students without a software development background a hands-on immersion in the toolsets, processes, and programming languages used in the development of web properties.
The goal of the class is to prepare non-developers to work successfully with developers - to learn what they need to know to collaborate with technologists on a day-to-day basis.? Working in small teams in an agile software development environment, students will work with version control tools, collaborative programming, front-end web development languages (HTML, CSS, Javascript), and frameworks including SASS, JQuery, React, Ember and Angular.

overview_of_class: This course focuses on imparting methods, theory, and practical experience in the field of design research in order to help define innovative products, services, and businesses in media and journalism. Students will be exposed to interviewing and observational techniques from anthropology, psychology, and sociology; interpretive techniques from literature, psychology, and business strategy; and creative methods and prototyping techniques from engineering, design, marketing, and advertising. By the end of this course, students will have a firm grounding in how to study a small number of people, uncover patterns in their thinking and behavior that point to design opportunities for news media products and services, and understand how to quickly test and improve ideas that solve for these opportunities. This course has roots in, and a similar arc to, fundamental design research courses taught in major design programs, inside major corporations, by influential consultancies, and in the most prominent startup accelerator, Matter Ventures.

overview_of_class: For one full quarter, students will work two or three days a week at a Bay Area company, focused on building media/tech products and/or making them more successful. The goal is for students to get hands-on experience that helps them develop new skills, sharpen existing ones and develop a deeper understanding of media innovation and product development. Students will file weekly reflections on their internships and meet several times during the quarter with the professor and other students to discuss their experiences. Each student will be expected to present once to the group about their experiences and/or lessons learned, and to write a reflective assessment at the end of the quarter about what they learned from the internship.

overview_of_class: Students will explore innovation and business opportunities in the center of the world's technology industry. Starting with business fundamentals in media and technology industries, they will learn to recognize opportunities for disruption, assess the competitive landscape, and evaluate innovation strategies. For the product ideas they are developing, they will identify possible business models that would make them sustainable. The course aims to inspire students to be the force of innovation in media technology companies of any size, from the start-up venture to the conglomerate.

overview_of_class:
Chicago is steeped in the immigrant tradition and alive right now with the energy and natural chaos of recent arrivals to the city and suburbs. It is also at the fulcrum of the tug of war between President Trump's emerging policies and the city's and county's pledges to the immigrants, refugees, and their families and communities who are directly impacted by the Trump presidency.

As mainstream journalism chases Trump's rhetoric, antics and policy fulminations, we will focus on the people who are impacted by it all. That is the raison d'être for social justice journalism.

The course will explore what differentiates social justice journalism from traditional journalism in terms of norms, ethics, sourcing, story generation, audience, relationships with communities, advocacy/detachment, profitability/sustainability, and proprietary/cooperative access and distribution.

It will also provide you opportunities to tell multimedia immigrant and refugee stories for publication. By focusing on global immigration and refugee phenomena, with a vigilant eye on national policy and rhetoric, the course will expose you to the communities where immigrants and refugees live and work, and in partnership with Immigrant Connect, an online network for immigrants, refugees, their families and communities, and with cooperating social justice outlets, you will produce stories that matter and that animate the lives of those who give you access to their experiences and families.

There are sources aplenty. The Chicago area ranks 5th among metropolitan areas in immigrant and refugee populations. Chicago itself is more than 20% foreign born; home to almost 600,000 immigrants and refugees. Suburban Cook County is home to even more. 
 
Immigrant groups aren't monolithic. They have both divergent and shared needs and interests. More than 50 percent of the Chicago-area immigrants, for instance, were born in three completely distinct parts of the world - Mexico, Poland, and India. Moreover, the balance of the immigrant population is even more diverse, with no country of origin comprising more than five percent of the population. In some ways, though, aggregate statistics or assumptions on the foreign born do more to mask their characteristics and concerns than to illuminate them. Through stories, we cross ethnic, cultural, neighborhood and generational lines to document immigrant experiences that are as varied as the people involved. Though those stories surface every day, they often go untold, unshared and unappreciated.

overview_of_class: Years ago, many of the nation's most significant and polarizing issues surfaced during election season, then popped up only sporadically after the votes were cast. Those days are gone. The permanent campaign surrounds us and it demands expert coverage. Pick an issue - immigration, taxes, health care, guns, climate change, voting rights, abortion, aging, LGBTQ rights, religious liberty, school choice - and you will discover a 24/7 effort to advance a cause or to defeat it. In this seminar, we will explore the issues and ideology, the personalities and political messaging, that define policy debates and election campaigns alike. We'll study smart, engaging coverage and develop strategies for building sources and expertise. For your final project, expect to choose an issue that matters to you and go deep.

overview_of_class: This course aims to help you better understand the building blocks that shape political campaigns and policy debates, such as polls, advertising, debates, focus groups, fundraising, big data, and free media (external or internal airtime on TV, radio, digital platforms, etc.). This will be both a lecture and reporting class with a series of assignments designed to enhance your ability to write about those pieces of the political process.
